title: UtiliChain
author: UtiliChain
content: Hey Bitcoiners, let’s pause the euphoria for a moment and talk about something important. Everyone’s buzzing about Bitcoin replacing gold, becoming a reserve asset for companies and countries, or even a way to save for your kids’ inheritance. It sounds amazing—but what if I told you there’s a major Achilles’ heel we’re overlooking? Something that could destroy Bitcoin as easily as a movie villain stealing the moon. Yes, I’m talking about a 51% attack. Let’s unpack this in simple terms.We all know Bitcoin’s security relies on mining—the computational power that keeps the network safe. Currently, the network’s hash rate is an eye-watering 700-800 EH/s (that’s 800 quintillion hashes per second). It sounds impenetrable, right? But here’s the kicker: to control 51% of the network and wreak havoc, you’d need a mining platform that costs around $20-30 billion. Expensive? Sure. Impossible? Not really.This cost estimate is based on today’s top-tier mining hardware, like the Antminer S21 Pro, which offers a hash rate of 150 TH/s at a price of around $4,000 per unit. To match 51% of the current hash rate (approximately 390 EH/s), you would need about 2.6 million of these machines. Add to this the infrastructure costs, such as data centers, cooling systems, and energy consumption, and the total climbs to the $20-30 billion range. This is a back-of-the-envelope calculation but provides a realistic ballpark figure.To put that in perspective, the cost of Elon Musk buying Twitter was $44 billion. Companies like OpenAI and xAI are building AI supercomputers costing tens of billions. Apple has over hundred billion in cash reserves. One determined billionaire or company with the resources and the motivation could theoretically destroy Bitcoin. That’s a chilling thought, isn’t it?You might say: “Who would spend billions just to destroy Bitcoin? It makes no sense!” True, it’s not logical to us Bitcoin believers. But do we want to rely on a “Proof-of-Clever-Guy” argument for security? Remember, logic doesn’t always stop bad actors. A rogue state, a rival financial system, or even an eccentric billionaire who just wants to watch the world burn could decide to make Bitcoin their target. Just because it’s irrational doesn’t mean it’s impossible.Let’s say this hypothetical villain executes the attack. What happens? The attacker could double-spend coins, invalidate transactions, or sow so much distrust that the Bitcoin economy collapses. People lose confidence, and what was once a “store of value” turns into chaos. The dream of Bitcoin as digital gold? Poof. Gone.So what’s the solution? One idea is to involve computational giants around the world in the network itself. Imagine a scenario where their vast computing power becomes part of the network. Of course, these companies wouldn’t just abandon their primary tasks to mine Bitcoin. They’d continue performing their usual computations but remain capable of contributing to the network’s security when needed. This is where something like a “Proof-of-Result” approach could play a role. If you’re curious about this concept, check out some of my other posts for more details.Bitcoin is an incredible innovation, but let’s not get so caught up in the hype that we ignore potential threats. If Bitcoin is to become the backbone of the global financial system, we must address these vulnerabilities. Otherwise, one bad actor (such as Vector from Despicable Me) might just come along and ruin it for everyone.Let’s discuss this—not out of fear, but because we care about Bitcoin’s future. What are your thoughts? Is this a real concern, or am I just being a pessimist?

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: Just because a risk exists within a technology does not mean it is a sufficient reason to avoid engaging with that technology altogether. Car accidents are one of the most common causes of death, yet this risk alone is not a valid reason to reject the concept of cars, and go back to horses. Bitcoin, among many other things, is a technology that enables the existence of a completely free-market based money without central planners. It relies on a game theory. Other forms of money rely on different assumptions, assumptions that one could argue are more frequently undermined than those of bitcoin. You pick the one money that works best for you.

comments.author: ranochigo
comments.body: If you cannot control the existing 390EH of hashrate, then you need 781EH of the hashrate. Most ASIC manufacturers cannot realistically supply anyone with that much ASICs and the space required for such an attack as well as the opportunity cost of doing so is far higher than what's worth. Most billionaires, or anyone with too much money don't actually have that many billions to spare. With the world being more and more exposed to Bitcoin, these attacks by adversaries are far less likely.Your proposal seems to have misunderstood the game theory aspect of a distributed network, or what PoW is really for. Send us a peer reviewed paper of your "Proof of Results" if you want any serious responses.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: There are a couple of problems with this type of scenarios, some of which was pointed out.For starters you can't carry out a 51% attack with money. You need hardware, and ASICs do not grow on trees. It is nearly impossible to gain control of the 51% of the existing hardware that is spread around the globe and owned by various individuals who do mining themselves and are not willing to sell it. New hardware is not easy to produce as well, not to mention we would be talking about additional hashrate not 51% of existing hardware.Secondly you are forgetting about the objective. Bitcoin will be hurt if a successful 51% attack were to take place but it will not be destroyed or disappear. That means governments and businesses who see bitcoin as a threat won't have the incentive to carry out that attack. Not to mention they have easier ways to prevent bitcoin adoption and hurt it like making it illegal if they wanted to.That leaves "crazy billionaires"! but do we really have one of those? Most importantly will they burn tens of billions of dollar? Because that's what would happen to their money invested in ASICs which would be bricked after the attack and will be worth nothing...

comments.author: UtiliChain
comments.body: QuoteBut I think that the matter of fact is that there are not millions of mining machines out there available. The ASIC designers don't make that many, because mining is a specialized market with only a few customers, so making more ASICs would actually lower the price of a miner (and put them out of business, because they still have to pay TSMC).As global computational power continues to grow, driven largely by advancements in AI and related industries, it’s unlikely that Bitcoin mining power will scale at the same rate. This is primarily due to the diminishing mining rewards over time, which could reduce incentives for miners to invest in expanding their operations. Additionally, as older mining hardware becomes more accessible and affordable, it might lower the barrier for potential attackers to accumulate significant hashing power. This could make the feasibility of a 51% attack more realistic in the future, especially if the network’s total hash rate stagnates or declines.
